entry.title: Pashinyan, Mirzoyan arrive in New York for UN general assembly

media:group.media:title: Pashinyan, Mirzoyan arrive in New York for UN general assembly
media:group.media:description:
üìç Armenia‚Äôs Foreign Ministry told CivilNet it has no information if any Armenians were among those killed or wounded in Israel‚Äôs strikes across Lebanon yesterday. üìç Armenia‚Äôs prime minister, Nikol Pashinyan, and foreign minister, Ararat Mirzoyan, arrived in New York for the United Nations General Assembly. üìç Ladislav Hamran, the head of Eurojust, the European Union agency that fights serious cross-border and organized crime, arrived in Armenia to sign a cooperation agreement. üìç Interview with Hrair Balian: youtube.com/watch?v=hD0i2H2Fsag

entry.title: Why won‚Äôt Yerevan act as Armenians still languish in Baku prisons?

media:group.media:title: Why won‚Äôt Yerevan act as Armenians still languish in Baku prisons?
media:group.media:description:
Hrair Balian, a longtime peacebuilding practitioner and consultant on international conflict resolution, sits down with CivilNet‚Äôs Mark Dovich to break down how the Armenian government has mishandled the critical issue of securing the release of Armenians held by Azerbaijan. He also explains his call on world leaders to boycott COP29, this year‚Äôs global climate summit, which Baku will host in November.
0:00 What are the cardinal rules for hostage negotiations? 8:37 Is a sustainable peace possible without releasing prisoners? 10:32 Why should world leaders boycott the COP29 conference?

media:group.media:title: Armenia celebrates Independence Day
media:group.media:description:
üìç Armenia celebrated its 33rd Independence Day with Prime Minister Nikol Pashinyan pledging to continue fostering the country‚Äôs security and democracy. üìç Bagrat Galstanyan held a rally with his supporters, gathering a crowd of people for the first time since June, and announcing a new protest scheduled for October 2. üìç Canadian Foreign Minister Melanie Joly issued a statement, condemning Azerbaijan‚Äôs ethnic cleansing of Nagorno-Karabakh‚Äôs Armenians last September and calling for continued negotiations. üìç THIS WEEK IN BUSINESS: youtu.be/XDzelR6WfI4?si=kT4ZugMZ-7szECAd üìç Gurumiran performs live at CivilNet: youtu.be/pjBp3yisWoY?si=Q8vLGwOA1UwCRVuN

entry.title: The Collapse of the Soviet Union: Roundtable Discussion

media:group.media:title: The Collapse of the Soviet Union: Roundtable Discussion
media:group.media:description:
Anatol Lieven, Sheila Fitzpatrick, Svetlana Savranskaya, and Thomas Graham held a roundtable discussion titled ‚ÄúCollapse of the Soviet Union‚Äù at a symposium on Russia organized by the Monterey Initiative in Russian Studies at the Middlebury Institute of International Studies at Monterey. The discussion took place on July 7, 2024, in Tbilisi and was moderated by distinguished historian Ronald Grigor Suny.
Anatol Lieven is an author, journalist, and policy analyst. He is a visiting professor at King's College London and a senior fellow at the Quincy Institute for Responsible Statecraft.
Sheila Fitzpatrick is an Australian historian renowned for her expertise on Soviet and modern Russian history, particularly during Joseph Stalin‚Äôs rule.
Svetlana Savranskaya is the director of Russia programs at the National Security Archives in the United States.
Thomas Graham was special assistant to the U.S. president on Russia from 2004 to 2007. He is a distinguished fellow at the Council on Foreign Relations
This year‚Äôs Monterey Summer Symposium on Russia took place in Yerevan, Tbilisi, and Istanbul from July 1 to July 20.

entry.title: Armenia welcomes Google delegation on first-of-its-kind visit: THIS WEEK IN BUSINESS

media:group.media:title: Armenia welcomes Google delegation on first-of-its-kind visit: THIS WEEK IN BUSINESS
media:group.media:description:
üìç A delegation from Google visited Armenia for first-of-their-kind talks with the country‚Äôs high-tech industry minister to review potential business opportunities. üìç Prosecutors have still not charged anyone with a crime in connection with the collapse of Armenia‚Äôs state investment fund earlier this year, the Prosecutor General‚Äôs Office told the Fact Investigation Platform news site. An investigation remains ongoing. üìç Armenia is close to meeting the requirements that would allow it to leave the European Union‚Äôs aviation blacklist, the country‚Äôs infrastructure minister announced.
Credits: Ruptly

media:group.media:title: Gurumiran: Live for Independence vol.II
media:group.media:description:
’Ä’°’µ’°’Ω’ø’°’∂’´ ’°’∂’Ø’°’≠’∏÷Ç’©’µ’°’∂ 33-’°’¥’µ’°’Ø’´ ’°’º’©’´’æ Gurumiran ’≠’∏÷Ç’¥’¢’® ’∞’µ’∏÷Ç÷Ä’®’∂’Ø’°’¨’æ’•÷Å ’ç’´’æ’´’¨’Ü’•’©’´ ’∫’°’ø’∑’£’°’¥’¢’∏÷Ç’¥÷â
Gurumiran ’≠’∏÷Ç’¥’¢’® ’Ω’ø’•’≤’Æ’•’¨ ’ß ’¨’´’¢’°’∂’°’∂’°’∞’°’µ ’Ñ’´÷Ä’°’∂ ‘≥’∏÷Ç÷Ä’∏÷Ç’∂’µ’°’∂’®÷â ’Ñ’´÷Ä’°’∂’® ‘≤’•’µ÷Ä’∏÷Ç’©’´÷Å ’ß, 2020-’´’∂ ’î’∏’æ’´’§’´, ’°’∫’° ‘≤’•’µ÷Ä’∏÷Ç’©’∏÷Ç’¥ ’ø’•’≤’´ ’∏÷Ç’∂’•÷Å’°’Æ ’∫’°’µ’©’µ’∏÷Ç’∂’´÷Å ’∞’•’ø’∏ ’ø’•’≤’°÷É’∏’≠’æ’•’¨ ÷á ’∞’°’Ω’ø’°’ø’æ’•’¨ ’ß ’Ä’°’µ’°’Ω’ø’°’∂’∏÷Ç’¥÷â ’Ñ’´÷Ä’°’∂’´ ’Ω’ø’•’≤’Æ’°’£’∏÷Ä’Æ’∏÷Ç’©’µ’∏÷Ç’∂’∂’•÷Ä’® ’∏’£’•’∑’∂’π’æ’°’Æ ’•’∂ ’¥’∑’°’Ø’∏÷Ç’©’°’µ’´’∂ ’¢’°’¶’¥’°’¶’°’∂ ’°’¶’§’•÷Å’∏÷Ç’©’µ’∏÷Ç’∂’∂’•÷Ä’´÷Å÷â Gurumiran ’≠’¥’¢’´ ’°’º’°’ª’´’∂ ’°’¨’¢’∏’¥’® ’¨’∏÷Ç’µ’Ω ’ß ’ø’•’Ω’•’¨ 2015-’´’∂÷â ’Ü÷Ä’°’∂÷Ñ ’Ω’ø’•’≤’Æ’°’£’∏÷Ä’Æ’∏÷Ç’¥ ’•’∂ ’∞’°’µ’•÷Ä’•’∂, ’°’∂’£’¨’•÷Ä’•’∂, ’°÷Ä’°’¢’•÷Ä’•’∂ ÷á ÷Ü÷Ä’°’∂’Ω’•÷Ä’•’∂÷â ‘Ω’¥’¢’´ Notes from Underground ’°’¨’¢’∏’¥’® ’Ø’©’∏’≤’°÷Ä’Ø’æ’´ 2025-’´’∂÷â
CivilNet hosted the Gurumiran band for an exclusive performance to mark Armenia‚Äôs independence day on September 21.
Gurumiran was created by Lebanese Armenian artist and musician Miran Gurunian, who relocated to Yerevan from Beirut after the COVID-19 pandemic and port explosion in 2020. Miran says his creations are inspired by his diverse cultural influences, and since his band‚Äôs debut in 2015, Gurumiran has made music in Armenian, English, Arabic, and French. The band's newest album, ‚ÄúNotes from Underground,‚Äù will be released next year.
